headline: Tesla Sank Today -- Is the Stock a Buy Right Now?
summary: Tesla stock fell Tuesday in conjunction with multiple bearish catalysts.  Elon Musk's feud with Trump was a factor in the sell-off, but concerns about vehicle shipments could have been a bigger factor.  Tesla has plenty of long-term growth opportunities, but its near-term outlook seems challenging.

headline: Tesla Q2 deliveries, June ADP employment data: What to Watch
summary: Asking for a Trend host Josh Lipton takes a look at the top stories for investors to watch on Wednesday, July 2. Tesla (TSLA) will be reporting its delivery numbers for the second quarter. Analysts are expecting 389,400 — an increase from Tesla's first quarter deliveries. ADP employment data for the month of June will be published, as economists expect an increase from the month prior in private payrolls. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend here.

headline: Car Sales Cooled in June as Trump Bump Fades
summary: The U.S. auto industry’s Trump bump was short-lived.  New-vehicle retail sales appear set to dip in June to the slowest pace in a year, a reversal from early spring when consumers raced to snap up new cars before tariffs kicked in.  General Motors Ford Motor Toyota  and most other automakers reported their latest sales Tuesday, quantifying the latest twist in the industry’s roller-coaster ride since the Trump administration rolled out sweeping duties on imported cars and car parts.

headline: These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Tesla, Sunrun, Robinhood, Wolfspeed, Las Vegas Sands, Progress Software, and More
summary: The  rose sharply after the Senate narrowly passed President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill.  CEO Elon Musk criticized Trump’s bill, calling it “utterly insane and destructive,” while the president suggested that the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE)–the department Musk helped run until the end of May–should look into his companies’ government subsidies.  Sunrun  jumped 11%,  SolarEdge Technologies  rose 7.2%, and solar and wind stocks soared as Republican legislators stripped an excise tax on renewable energy projects from Trump’s bill.

raw.headline: These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Tesla, Sunrun, Robinhood, Wolfspeed, Las Vegas Sands, Progress Software, and More
raw.summary: The  rose sharply after the Senate narrowly passed President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill.  CEO Elon Musk criticized Trump’s bill, calling it “utterly insane and destructive,” while the president suggested that the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE)–the department Musk helped run until the end of May–should look into his companies’ government subsidies.  Sunrun  jumped 11%,  SolarEdge Technologies  rose 7.2%, and solar and wind stocks soared as Republican legislators stripped an excise tax on renewable energy projects from Trump’s bill.

headline: Trump vs. Musk 2.0: Reignited feud sends Tesla stock lower
summary: Tesla (TSLA) stock slides as CEO Elon Musk and President Trump are yet again arguing over social media. Musk criticized Trump's big, beautiful bill, which moves to the House after narrowly passing through the Senate, saying the mega bill, which is expected to add trillions to the national debt, is "insane." The president responded by threatening to cut US government subsidies to Musk's businesses, including Tesla and SpaceX (SPAX.PVT). Trump added that the richest man in the world would then have to "close up shop and head back home to South Africa." Yahoo Finance's Head of News, Myles Udland, and Prairie Operating Co. executive vice president of market strategy and TheBigSkinny.com founder, Lou Basenese, sit down with Josh Lipton on Market Domination to discuss the latest. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Electric-Vehicle Sales Fall in the Second Quarter
summary: U.S. car buyers continue to sour on electric vehicles.  Ford Motor, Hyundai and Kia on Tuesday all reported steep declines in EV sales for the second quarter, with Ford saying its fell more than 30% and Kia saying sales of two models dropped by half.  Fully electric vehicles also have especially lost share to hybrid-electric vehicles, which are an easier leap for many consumers, said Tyson Jominy, J.D. Power's senior vice president of data and analytics.

headline: Tesla sales rise in Norway and Spain, boosted by Model Y
summary: STORY: Tesla sales rose in Norway and Spain in June, an early sign that some are buying its newly-revamped Model Y vehicle.Tesla had seen sales plunge in recent months to multi-year lows in its key European markets as CEO Elon Musk's relationship with U.S. President Donald Trump and embrace of far-right politics in Europe led to protests against his company, as well as vandalism at its showrooms and charging stations.The EV maker has suffered six straight year-over-year losses in quarterly new registration volumes across Western Europe, according to data from Schmidt Automotive, which said Tesla was on track for a seventh straight year-on-year loss.Tesla had not launched a new mainstream model since 2020, while traditional automakers have been rushing to produce more affordable electric cars.Meanwhile, Chinese rivals, such as BYD, have been rapidly taking market share.But the revamped Model Y, which arrived in many European markets in May and June, has helped boost Tesla's fortunes.Sales in Norway spiked last month by 54% annually, with Model Y sales up 115%, results the head of the Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association called "impressive."And in Spain, June sales increased by 60% annually, with Model Y sales up nearly 130%.The June data comes amid a renewed dispute between Musk and Trump regarding the U.S. president's sweeping tax-cut and spending bill.Shares of Tesla were down more than 4% in Tuesday morning trading.

raw.headline: Tesla sales rise in Norway and Spain, boosted by Model Y
raw.summary: STORY: Tesla sales rose in Norway and Spain in June, an early sign that some are buying its newly-revamped Model Y vehicle.Tesla had seen sales plunge in recent months to multi-year lows in its key European markets as CEO Elon Musk's relationship with U.S. President Donald Trump and embrace of far-right politics in Europe led to protests against his company, as well as vandalism at its showrooms and charging stations.The EV maker has suffered six straight year-over-year losses in quarterly new registration volumes across Western Europe, according to data from Schmidt Automotive, which said Tesla was on track for a seventh straight year-on-year loss.Tesla had not launched a new mainstream model since 2020, while traditional automakers have been rushing to produce more affordable electric cars.Meanwhile, Chinese rivals, such as BYD, have been rapidly taking market share.But the revamped Model Y, which arrived in many European markets in May and June, has helped boost Tesla's fortunes.Sales in Norway spiked last month by 54% annually, with Model Y sales up 115%, results the head of the Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association called "impressive."And in Spain, June sales increased by 60% annually, with Model Y sales up nearly 130%.The June data comes amid a renewed dispute between Musk and Trump regarding the U.S. president's sweeping tax-cut and spending bill.Shares of Tesla were down more than 4% in Tuesday morning trading.

summary: Investors were turning their attention to the Senate’s attempts to pass President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill and global trade talks.  CEO Elon Musk criticized Trump’s bill, calling it “utterly insane and destructive,” while the president suggest that the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE)–the department Musk helped run until the end of May–should look into his companies’ government subsidies. headline: France car registrations down 6.7% in June, Tesla sales drop 10%
summary: New car registrations in France slid 6.7% in June from a year earlier to 169,504 vehicles, data from French car body PFA showed on Tuesday. Tesla sales fell 10.04% to 3,646 vehicles last month. Since the beginning of the year, Tesla's sales have slumped by 39.59% while the French market overall has shrunk by 7.94% over the same period.

raw.headline: France car registrations down 6.7% in June, Tesla sales drop 10%
raw.summary: New car registrations in France slid 6.7% in June from a year earlier to 169,504 vehicles, data from French car body PFA showed on Tuesday. headline: Tesla 'detached from fundamentals' amid weak delivery outlook
summary: Tesla (TSLA) investors are bracing for the company's delivery numbers to be released on Wednesday, which are anticipated to be weak. Analysts warn that weak results could drag earnings estimates even lower ahead of the company's second quarter earnings results. Washington Crossing Advisors senior portfolio manager Chad Morganlander, Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Allie Canal, and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma join Opening Bid host Brian Sozzi to discuss how Tesla's lofty valuation stacks up against mounting competition and fading fundamentals. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid here.

headline: Bond market is 'biggest near-term risk' for stocks right now
summary: Debt concerns are rising after warnings from Bridgewater Associates founder Ray Dalio and Tesla CEO Elon Musk about President Trump's tax bill, but the 10-year yield (^TNX) isn't reacting sharply. Washington Crossing Advisors senior portfolio manager Chad Morganlander, Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Allie Canal, and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma join Opening Bid host Brian Sozzi to weigh in on bond yield (^TYX, ^TNX, ^FVX) movements and discuss how tariffs are hitting consumer spending. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid here.
